Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply marked with main features, misshapen and now much rubbed, with clypeus, prothorax and elytra just visible; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside incised with three hieroglyphic signs arranged vertically with from top to bottom Ra (sun-disc), men (draughtboard) and hat (lion forepart); longitudinally pierced; glaze gone; fine core dirty, off white in colour; all surface eroded.
Curator's comments: This scarab was likely produced in the 'Scarab Factory' at Naukratis (on this production, see: Gorton 1996, 9-131; Webb forthcoming). It could belong to Gorton type XXVIII B (Gorton 1996, 103-105), though the inscription on the underside is incised, not stamped. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 46)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.122) (phase 3)
